content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been struggling to sleep, and I think it’s mostly because of stress at work. My mind just keeps racing at night, and it’s making me feel exhausted during the day. My partner convinced me to talk to someone, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been really challenging for you lately, with stress affecting your sleep and leaving you exhausted. It’s great that you’re open to talking about it, and it shows a lot of strength that you’re here now. What’s been going on at work that’s been contributing to the stress?

Well, work has been pretty tough lately because I’m really worried about losing my job. The company’s not doing great, and I feel like I’m on the chopping block if layoffs happen. It’s just a constant weight on my mind.

That sounds like a heavy burden to carry, especially when your job feels uncertain, and it makes sense that it’s affecting your sleep. It must be hard having this worry follow you through the day and even into the night. How are you managing everything right now, with work and the stress it’s bringing?

I try to stay focused, but it’s constantly in the back of my mind. At night, I end up scrolling on my phone because it feels like the only way to distract myself from all the thoughts, but I know it’s probably making things worse. I just don’t know how else to stop my mind from racing.

It sounds like you’re trying to cope the best you can, but the endless scrolling might not be giving you the relief you need. You’re aware that it’s likely not helping, which shows you’re already thinking critically about what’s working for you and what isn’t. Have there been times you’ve felt calmer or anything that has helped slow down those racing thoughts, even briefly?

Not really, to be honest. It feels like my brain's constantly in overdrive, especially at night. The only thing that sometimes works is if I’m completely exhausted, but even then, it doesn’t guarantee I’ll sleep well.

It sounds like you’re caught in a tough cycle, feeling drained but unable to fully rest when you need it the most. Being in that state of mental overdrive every night must feel overwhelming. What do you think could help lighten that mental load or bring a bit of ease to your mind?

I don't know. Maybe if I could somehow get out of my head or stop worrying so much, but I'm not sure how to do that. The stress feels constant, and even thinking about ways to manage it adds to the pressure. I guess I don’t even know where to start.

It makes sense that the constant stress feels overwhelming, and even thinking about how to manage it can feel like piling on more pressure. You’re navigating a lot at once, which is bound to be draining. You’ve already shown that you’re willing to explore ways to feel better by speaking here today, and that’s a really important first step. What’s most important to you right now—whether that’s sleep, work stress, or something else?

I think right now, it’s a mix of everything—wanting to sleep better, but also figuring out how to deal with the stress at work. And honestly, I just don’t want all of this to spill over into my family life. That’s what matters most to me—being there for my partner and kids. It’s just hard to figure out where to even begin.

Family is clearly very important to you, and it’s meaningful that you’re thinking about how all of this impacts your partner and kids while navigating your own stress. Caring about that connection shows a lot about your values and the kind of person you want to be, even during tough times. With so much happening, it’s understandable that figuring out where to start feels daunting. What would support look like to you right now—whether for yourself or for your family?

I think just having some kind of clarity would help. Maybe figuring out how to manage the work stress or learning how to quiet my thoughts at night. I don’t want to let all of this overwhelm me to the point where I’m disconnected from my family. I just want to feel a little more in control.

It’s clear you really care about staying present for your family, and wanting to feel more in control is such a thoughtful goal amidst everything you’re facing. Having clarity—whether it’s managing work stress or your thoughts at night—sounds like an important step for you. Is there one area you’d like to start focusing on more right now, or would you like to explore both together?

I think right now, focusing on quieting my thoughts at night might be a good place to start. If I could sleep better, I might have more energy and clarity to handle the work stress. It feels like everything’s connected, so maybe starting there would help. What do you think?

That makes a lot of sense—the connection between sleep, energy, and clarity is really important, and focusing on quieting your mind at night sounds like a thoughtful place to begin. It shows a lot of insight that you’re seeing how improving one area might support you overall. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before exploring ways to approach this?
No, I think quieting my mind at night is the main thing for now. I'm open to hearing suggestions if you have any.

Thank you for sharing your thoughts and being open to exploring ideas. Just to summarize, you’ve been dealing with stress at work that’s affected your sleep and, in turn, your energy and ability to stay present with your family. Quieting your mind at night feels like the right starting point to help you. Would it be okay to talk now about some approaches you could try for this?
Yeah, that sounds good. I'm willing to hear some ideas, though I can’t promise I’ll be great at sticking to them right away.

It’s completely okay if sticking to them takes time—starting out and exploring ideas is already a big step forward, and it’s normal to take things at your own pace. One option could be creating a relaxing nighttime routine to help signal to your mind that it’s time to wind down. Some people find trying things like journaling to release racing thoughts or breathing exercises to calm the body helpful before bed. How do those sound to you, or is there something specific you had in mind that feels more doable?
